Description: Pratt & Whitney and its subcontractor, PCC Airfoils LLC, agreed to pay the United States a total of $52,325,000 to resolve False Claims Act allegations that they knowingly sold defective turbine blade replacements for jet engines used in military aircraft. Pratt's share included a payment of $45.5 million and services worth $4.825 million.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2008/August/08-civ-675.html

Description: Pratt & Whitney and its subcontractor, PCC Airfoils LLC, agreed to pay the United States a total of $52,325,000 to resolve False Claims Act allegations that they knowingly sold defective turbine blade replacements for jet engines used in military aircraft. PCC's share of the settlement was $2 million.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2008/August/08-civ-675.html

Description: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Ohio found United Technologies Corporation liable for over $473 million in damages and penalties arising out of a contract to provide the Air Force with fighter aircraft engines for F-15 and F-16 aircraft between 1985 and 1990. The company later appealed and won a reduction in the damages to just over $11 million. Description: United Technologies and its subsidiaries Hamilton Sundstrand Corporation and Pratt & Whitney Canada Corp. all agreed to pay more than $75 million as part of a global settlement with the Justice Department and State Department in connection with the illegal export to China of military software for helicopters and for making false and belated disclosures to the U.S. government about these illegal exports. Pratt & Whitney Canada pleaded guilty on two counts while it and United Techologies and Hamilton Sundstrand received deferred prosecution agreeements for the others.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/usao/ct/Press2012/20120628.html

Description: A jury awarded the plaintiff in this age and gender discrimination case $1.5 million in economic damages and $7 million in punitive damages but the court reduced the latter to $1 million. The final award also included $800,000 in legal fees. A state appeals court upheld the revised verdict in ruling no. B278517.
Court: Superior Court of State of California, County of Los Angeles
Private Litigation Case Title: BLANCA TORRES vs. B E AEROPSACE INC ET AL
Info Source: https://www.shrm.org/resourcesandtools/legal-and-compliance/state-and-local-updates/pages/employee-can-keep-$2.5m-award-in-age-and-gender-bias-case.aspx
